DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Vessels carrying out transport operations involving certain substances constituting health hazards

DataDictionaryReference.Name: three blue lights / cones
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Vessels carrying out transport operations involving certain explosives

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Current velocity at high water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The rate of travel of a current at a high water level

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Current velocity at low water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The rate of travel of a current at a low water level

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Current velocity at mean water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The rate of travel of a current at a mean water level

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Current velocity at other water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The rate of travel of a current at an other water level

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Description of legal conditions
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Additional textual information which is related to the numerical description of the particular arti-cle/clause of the applicable law/regulation

DataDictionaryReference.Name: upstream
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: toward the source of a stream

DataDictionaryReference.Name: downstream
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: in the direction of flow of a current or stream

DataDictionaryReference.Name: to the left bank
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: toward the left side of the bank

DataDictionaryReference.Name: to the right bank
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: toward the right side of the bank

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Distance from notice mark, first
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Minimum distance of the impact of an area, which is signed by notice marks. The distance is measured from the notice mark rectangular to the bank

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Distance from notice mark, second
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Maximum distance of the impact of an area, which is signed by notice marks. The distance is measured from the notice mark rectangular to the bank

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Distance of impact, downstream
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Downstream distance of the impact of an area, which is signed by notice marks. The distance is normally given on an additional mark left and/or right of the notice mark

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Distance of impact, upstream
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Upstream distance of the impact of an area, which is signed by notice marks. The distance is normally given on an additional mark left and/or right of the notice mark

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Draught range value 1
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The minimum value of the draught range the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation is dealing with

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Draught range value 2
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximum value of the draught range the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation is dealing with

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Elevation 1 of surface (m)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The minimum (shoalest) value of an elevation range.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Elevation 2 of surface (m)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximum (highest) value of an elevation range

DataDictionaryReference.Name: prohibition mark
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: marks which indicate a prohibition

DataDictionaryReference.Name: regulation mark
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: marks which indicate a regulation

DataDictionaryReference.Name: restriction mark
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: marks which indicate a restriction

DataDictionaryReference.Name: recommendation mark
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: marks which indicate a recommendation

DataDictionaryReference.Name: information mark
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: marks with general information

DataDictionaryReference.Name: metres
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in metres (SI units of length)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: feet
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in feet (imperial units of length)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: kilometres
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in kilometres (1000 metres)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: hectometres
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in hectometres (100 metres)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: statute miles
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in statue (land) miles

DataDictionaryReference.Name: nautical miles
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in nautical (sea) miles

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Horizontal clearance length
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The length of an object, such as a lock or basin, which is available for safe navigation. This may, or may not, be the same as the total physical length (HORLEN) of the object

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Horizontal clearance width
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The width of an object, such as a lock or basin, which is available for safe navigation. This may, or may not, be the same as the total physical width (HORWID) of the object

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Length range value 1
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The minimum value of the length range the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation is dealing with

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Length range value 2
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximum value of the length range the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation is dealing with

DataDictionaryReference.Name: IALA A
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: navigational aids conform to the International Association of Lighthouse Authorities - IALA A system.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: IALA B
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: navigational aids conform to the International Association of Lighthouse Authorities - IALA B system.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: no system
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: navigational aids do not conform to any defined system.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: other sytem
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: navigational aids conform to a defined system other than International Association of Lighthouse Authorities -IALA.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: CEVNI
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: navigational aids conform to the European Code for Inland Waterways of UN/ECE.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Russian inland waterway regulations
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: navigational aids conform to the Russian inland waterway regulations.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Maximal permitted beam
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximal permitted beam (width of a ship's hull) of a vessel or convoy according to the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Maximal permitted draught
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximal permitted draught of a vessel or convoy according to the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Maximal permitted length
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximal permitted length of a vessel or convoy according to the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Maximal permitted speed
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximal permitted vessel speed according to the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Maximal permitted water displacement
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximal permitted water displacement of a vessel or convoy according to the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Name of other locally relevant water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Name of the water level, which is used for the attribute othwat (value at other locally relevant water level) including version identification, for example year of issue or period

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Name of relevant high water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Name of the water level, which is used for the attribute higwat (value at relevant high water level) including version identification, for example year of issue or period

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Name of relevant low water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Name of the water level, which is used for the attribute lowwat (value at relevant low water level) including version identification, for example year of issue or period

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Name of relevant mean water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Name of the water level, which is used for the attribute mawat (value at relevant mean water level) including version identification, for example year of issue or period

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Name of Sounding datum reference level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Name of the water level depth values are referred to

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Name of vertical river datum reference level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Name of the water level vertical clearance values are referred to

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Publication reference
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Waterway or waterway section for which a juridical regulation with respect to the maximum permitted vessel dimensions exists

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Baltic datum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Baltic Datum (Baltic Hights System) - The unified State system for absolute hights reckoning from Kronshtadt Tide-gauge Datum that is accepted in Russian Federation.(Hydrographic Terminology Dictionary, HDNO, 1984)-

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Adriatic level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The average height of the surface of the Adriatic sea at the tide station of Trieste in Italy.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Amsterdam Ordnance Datum (NAP)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Dutch gravitational reference level that is approximately the avarage summer height of the North Sea.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean Sea Level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MSL) - the average height of the surface of the sea at a tide station for all stages of the tide over a 19-year period, usually determined from hourly height readings measured from a fixed predetermined reference level. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3156)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: National Geodetic Vertical Datum - NGVD29
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The name, after May 10, 1973, of the Sea Level Datum of 1929.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: North American Vertical Datum - NAVD88
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The vertical control datum established in 1991 by the minimum-constraint adjustment of the Canadian-Mexican-U.S. leveling observations.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean sea level 1912
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A vertical control datum established for vertical control in the United States by the general adjustment of 1912.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean sea level 1929
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A vertical control datum established for vertical control in the United States by the general adjustment of 1929.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: anchoring prohibited
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an area within which anchoring is not permitted.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: anchoring restricted
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a specified area designated by appropriate authority, within which anchoring is restricted in accordance with certain specified conditions.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: entry prohibited
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an area within which navigation and/or anchoring is prohibited. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4044)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: entry restricted
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a specified area designated by appropriate authority, within which navigation is restricted in accordance with certain specified conditions. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4366)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: no wake
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: mariners must adjust the speed of their vessels to reduce the wave or wash which may cause erosion or disturb moored vessels.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: area to be avoided
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an IMO designated area to be avoided, defined as a routeing measure. (adapted from IHO Chart Specifications, M-4, 435.7)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: speed restricted
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an area within which speed is restricted.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: overtaking prohibited
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a specified area designated by appropriate authority, within which overtaking is generally prohibited

DataDictionaryReference.Name: overtaking of convoys by convoys prohibited
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a specified area designated by appropriate authority, within which overtaking between convoys prohibited

DataDictionaryReference.Name: passing or overtaking prohibited
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a specified area designated by appropriate authority, within which passing or overtaking is generally prohibited

DataDictionaryReference.Name: berthing prohibited
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a specified area designated by appropriate authority, within which vessels, assemblies of floating material or floating establishments may not berth.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: berthing restricted
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a specified area designated by appropriate authority, within which berthing is restricted

DataDictionaryReference.Name: making fast prohibited
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a specified area designated by appropriate authority, within which vessels, assemblies of floating material or floating establishments may not make fast to the bank.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: making fast restricted
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a specified area designated by appropriate authority, within which making fast to the bank is restricted

DataDictionaryReference.Name: turning prohibited
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a specified area designated by appropriate authority, within which all turning is generally prohibited

DataDictionaryReference.Name: restricted fairway depth
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an area within which the fairway depth is restricted.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: general cargo vessel
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a vessel which is designed for carrying general cargo, e.g. boxes, sacks.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: container vessel
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a vessel which is designed for carrying containers.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: tanker
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a vessel which is designed for carrying liquid goods, e.g. oil or water.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: sailing vessel
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a vessel that is powered by the wind; often having several masts.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: fishing vessel
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a vessel that is used and equipped for the fishing of living aquatic resources.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: special purpose vessel.
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a vessel that fulfills special purposes e.g. hovercrafts, pilot boats

DataDictionaryReference.Name: man of War
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: armed naval vessel.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: submarine
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a vessel that is capable of operating for an extended period of time underwater.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: bulk carrier
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a vessel which is designed for carrying bulk goods, e.g. coal, ore or grain.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: seaplane
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: airplane designed to take off from and alight on water.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: tugboat
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a powerful small boat designed to pull or push larger ships or powerless barges.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: passenger vessel
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a vessel which is designed for carrying passengers and which serves mainly as cruise vessel.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: ferry
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a vessel which is designed for carrying passengers, and sometimes their vehicles, on scheduled services.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: boat
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a small vessel.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Speed range value 1
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The minimum value of the speed range the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation is dealing with

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Speed range value 2
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximum value of the speed range the particular article/clause of the applicable law/regulation is dealing with

DataDictionaryReference.Name: speed over ground
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The vessels actual speed, determined by dividing the distance between successive fixes by the time between the fixes

DataDictionaryReference.Name: speed through water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The vessels actual speed, determined by substracting the speed over ground by the current speed

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Time Schedule Reference
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The string encodes the file name of an external file

DataDictionaryReference.Name: containers
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: boxes for cargo transport with standardized dimensions.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: bulk goods
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: unpacked bulk cargo in the same or a similar kind of nature (homogeneous).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: oil
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Mineral oil or liquid petrolatum, a by-product in the distillation of petroleum to produce gasoline.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: fuel
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: liquid fuel, e.g. gasoline, diesel.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: chemicals
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: any material used in or obtained by a process in chemistry.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: liquid goods
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: fluids whose shape is usually determined by the container it fills.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: explosive goods
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: goods that undergoes decomposition or combustion with great rapidity, evolving much heat and producing a large volume of gas.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: fish
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: marine animals

DataDictionaryReference.Name: cars
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: wheeled vehicles

DataDictionaryReference.Name: general cargo
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: general cargo

DataDictionaryReference.Name: UN location code
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The attribute unlocd should be used to encode the UN Location Code (http://www.unece.org/cefact/locode/service/main.htm) or - in Europe - the Inland Ship Reporting Standard (ISRS) Code
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The ISRS Code exists of: - UN country code (2 digits), - UN Location code (3 digits, XXX if not available), - Fairway section number (5 numerical digits, to be determined by the national authority; a side branch should have an own section number, when there are special restrictions, e.g. bridges), - terminal code or passage point code (5 alphanumerical digits, 00000if not available), - fairway section hectometre (5 numerical digits, hectometre at the cen-ter of the area, 00000if not available). If the ISRS code is not available, the code of the Nordersoft RIS-Index may be used

DataDictionaryReference.Name: liner trade
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: ship is used to carry goods on a scheduled service

DataDictionaryReference.Name: occasional professional shipping
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: ship is occasional used for professional shipping

DataDictionaryReference.Name: leisure
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: ship is used for leisure activities

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Value at other locally relevant water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Value at waterway gauge in case of a specific water level, which is locally of importanance or of interest for navigation

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Value at relevant high water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Value at waterway gauge in case of exact high water level (according to official regulations at the specific section of waterway)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Value at relevant low water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Value at waterway gauge in case of exact low water level (according to official regulations at the specific section of waterway)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Value at relevant mean water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Value at waterway gauge in case of exact mean water level (according to official regulations at the specific section of waterway)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean lower low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MLLW) - the average height of the lower low waters at a place over a 19-year period. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3145)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Local low water reference level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: low water reference level of the local area

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Local high water reference level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: high water reference level of the local area

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Local mean water reference level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: mean water reference level of the local area

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Equivalent height of water (German GlW)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A low water level which is the result of a defined low water discharge - called "equivalent discharge".
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: A new agreement upon the value of the "equivalent discharge" is made every 10 years by the "Central Commission for Navigation on the Rhine". On average the "equivalent height of water" is currently fallen short of only at about 10 days per year [2002]

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Highest Shipping Height of Water (German HSW)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: upper limit of water levels where navigation is allowed

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Reference low water level according to Danube Commission
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The water level at a discharge, which is exceeded 94 % of the year within a period of 30 years.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Highest shipping height of water according to Danube Commission
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The water level at a discharge, which is exceeded 1 % of the year within a period of 30 years.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Dutch river low water reference level (OLR)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The water level at a discharge, which is exceeded 95 % of the year within a period of 20 years.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Russian project water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Conditional low water level with established probability (Hydrographic Terminology Dictionary, HDNO, 1984).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Russian normal backwater level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Highest water level derived from the upper backwater stream in watercourse or reservoir under the normal operational conditions. (Hydrographic Terminology Dictionary, HDNO, 1984).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Water displacement range value 1
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The minimum value of the water displacement range the particular article/clause of the appli-cable law/regulation is dealing with

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Water displacement value 2
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximum value of the water displacement range the particular article/clause of the appli-cable law/regulation is dealing with

DataDictionaryReference.Name: partly submerged at high water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: partially covered and partially dry at high water.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: always dry
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: not covered at high water under average meteorological conditions.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: always under water/submerged
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: remains covered by water at all times under average meteorological conditions.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: above mean water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: above a water level called "mean water" which is the arithmetic mean value of all water levels within a certain period of time

DataDictionaryReference.Name: below mean water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: below a water level called "mean water" which is the arithmetic mean value of all water levels within a certain period of time

DataDictionaryReference.Name: waterway distance
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The distance measured from an origin of a river or canal

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Coverage
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A geographical area that describes the coverage and extent of spatial objects.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: This object class is intended to support an indication of coverage.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Quality of data
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area within which a uniform assessment of the quality of the data exists.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Survey reliability
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area within which a uniform assessment of the reliability of source survey information exists.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Administration Area (Named)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A defined (and possibly named) administration area.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Airport/airfield
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area containing at least one runway, used for landing, take-off, and movement of aircraft.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Beacon, lateral
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A beacon, is a prominent specially constructed object forming a conspicuous mark as a fixed aid to navigation or for use in hydrographic survey (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 420). A lateral beacon, is used to indicate the port or starboard hand side of the route to be followed. They are generally used for well defined channels and are used in conjunction with a conventional direction of buoyage. (UKHO NP 735, 5th Edition)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Buoy, cardinal
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A buoy, is a floating object moored to the bottom in a particular place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes. (IHO Dictionary S-32 5th Edition, 565).A cardinal buoy, is used in conjunction with the compass to indicate where the mariner may find the best navigable water. It is placed in one of the four quadrants (North, East, South and West), bounded by inter-cardinal bearings from the point marked. (UKHO NP 735, 5th Edition)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Buoy, lateral
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A buoy, is a floating object moored to the bottom in a particular place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 565). A lateral buoy, is used to indicate the port or starboard hand side of the route to be followed. They are generally used for well defined channels and are used in conjunction with a conventional direction of buoyage. (UKHO NP 735, 5th Edition)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Buoy, safe water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A buoy, is a floating object moored to the bottom in a particular place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 565). A safe water buoy, is used to indicate that there is navigable water around the mark. (UKHO NP735, 5th Edition)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: A safe water mark may be used as a centerline, mid-channel or landfall buoy, or to indicate the best point of passage under a fixed bridge. Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Buoy, special purpose/general
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A buoy, is a floating object moored to the bottom in a particular place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 565). A special purpose buoy, is primarily used to indicate an area or feature, the nature of which is apparent from reference to a chart, Sailing Directions or Notices to Mariners. (UKHO NP 735, 5th Edition). Buoy in general: A buoy, whose appearance or purpose is not adequately known.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Built-up area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area containing a concentration of buildings and the supporting road or rail infrastructure.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Building, single
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A relatively permanent structure, roofed and usually walled. It is designed for some particular use which it may be important to indicate. (Digital Geographic Information Working Group, Oct.87)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: This object class is used to encode single buildings, including those with a particular function or service of major interest.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Canal
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An artificial waterway with no flow, or a controlled flow, used for navigation, or for draining or irrigating land (ditch). (United States Geological Survey, Jan.89)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The object 'canal' describes the area of the canal, the object 'canal bank' the banks.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Cable area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area which contains one or more submarine cables.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Cable, submarine
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An assembly of wires or fibres, or a wire rope or chain which has been laid underwater or buried beneath the seabed (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Coastline
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The line where shore and water meet. Although the terminology of coasts and shores is rather confused, shoreline and coastline are generally used as synonyms. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 858,4695)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Caution area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Generally, an area where the mariner has to be made aware of circumstances influencing the safety of navigation.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: This object class may be required to identify: - a danger - a risk - a rule - advice which is not directly related to a specific object.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Conveyor
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A mechanical apparatus for moving bulk material or people from place to place (as by a moving belt or chain of receptacles).
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The conveyor supports are encoded as pylon/bridge supports (PYLONS).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Crane
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A machine for lifting, shifting and lowering objects or materials by means of a swinging boom or with a lifting apparatus supported on an overhead track. (Digital Geographic Information Working Group, Oct.87)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The position of a sheerlegs or a travelling crane is defined as its resting position.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Dam
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A barrier to check or confine anything in motion; particularly one constructed to hold back water and raise its level to form a reservoir, or to prevent flooding. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1196)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Daymark
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The identifying characteristics of an aid to navigation which serve to facilitate its recognition against a daylight viewing background. On those structures that do not by themselves present an adequate viewing area to be seen at the required distance, the aid is made more visible by affixing a daymark to the structure. A daymark so affixed has a distinctive colour and shape depending on the purpose of the aid. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1248)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Depth area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A depth area is a water area whose depth is within a defined range of values.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Intertidal areas are encoded as depth areas. These do not have to include soundings. The depth range within a depth area is defined by the attributes 'DRVAL1' and 'DRVAL2'.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Depth contour
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A line connecting points of equal water depth which is sometimes significantly displaced outside of soundings, symbols and other chart detail for clarity as well as generalization. Depth contours, therefore, often represent an approximate location of the line of equal depth as related to the surveyed line delineated on the source. Also referred to as depth curve. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1314, 1315)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Drying contours are encoded with negative values.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Dredged area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area of the bottom of a body of water which has been deepened by dredging. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1462)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Dry dock
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An artificial basin fitted with a gate or caisson, into which vessels can be floated and the water pumped out to expose the vessel's bottom. Also called graving dock. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1426)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Dyke
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A dyke (or dike) is an artificial embankment to contain or hold back water.(IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1361)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Fairway
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: That part of a river, harbour and so on, where the main navigable channel for vessels of larger size lies. It is also the usual course followed by vessels entering or leaving harbours, called 'ship channel'. (International Maritime Dictionary, 2nd Ed.)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Ferry route
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A route in a body of water where a ferry crosses from one shoreline to another. (Digital Geographic Information Working Group, Oct.87)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Floating dock
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A form of dry dock consisting of a floating structure of one or more sections which can be partly submerged by controlled flooding to receive a vessel, then raised by pumping out the water so that the vessel's bottom can be exposed. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1427)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Fence/wall
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A natural or man-made barrier used as an enclosure or boundary or for protection. (adapted from Digital Geographic Information Working Group, Oct.1987)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Fog signal
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A warning signal transmitted by a vessel, or aid to navigation, during periods of low visibility. Also, the device producing such a signal. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1890)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Free port area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A port where certain import and export duties are waived (unless goods pass into the country) to facilitate reshipment to other countries. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1927)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Gate
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A structure that may be swung, drawn, or lowered to block an entrance or passageway. (United States Geological Survey, Jan.89)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: This object class is used to encode gates that control the flow of water.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Harbour facility
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A harbour installation with a service or commercial operation of public interest.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Hulk
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A permanently moored ship.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Lake
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A large body of water entirely surrounded by land. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 2629)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Light
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A luminous or lighted aid to navigation. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 2766)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: A light may be fixed on a buoy, beacon, tower etc. These are separate objects.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Land area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The solid portion of the Earth's surface, as opposed to sea, water. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 2635)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Landmark
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A prominent object at a fixed location which can be used in determining a location or a direction. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 2643).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Land region
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area of natural scenery on land. It is defined by its geographical characteristics and may be known by its proper name.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mooring/Warping facility
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The equipment or structure used to secure a vessel (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3322)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Navigation line
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A navigation line is a straight line extending towards an area of navigational interest and generally generated by two navigational aids or one navigational aid and a bearing. (Service Hydrographique et Ocanographique de la Marine, France)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The portion of a navigation line that a ship should use for navigation is known as a recommended track. The extent of the navigation line depends on the visibility of the navigational aid(s). The attribute 'orientation' (ORIENT) specifies the orientation of the navigation line measured from the water towards the navigational aid(s). The recommended track is that portion of a 'navigation line' that a ship should use for navigation. (see below)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Obstruction
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: In marine navigation, anything that hinders or prevents movement, particularly anything that endangers or prevents passage of a vessel. The term is usually used to refer to an isolated danger to navigation... (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3503)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Oil barrier
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A construction to dam oil flow on water.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Pile
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A long heavy timber or section of steel, wood, concrete, etc.. forced into the earth which may serve as a support, as for a pier, or a free standing pole within a marine environment. (Adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3840)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Pipeline area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area containing one or more pipelines.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Pipeline, submarine/on land
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A pipeline is a string of interconnected pipes used for the transport of matter, nowadays mainly oil or gas. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3857). A submarine or land pipeline is a pipeline lying on or buried under the seabed or the land.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: It must be assumed that the pipes are vulnerable to damage from anchoring or trawling.... They may be a potential danger to navigation. (IHO Chart Specifications, M-4)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Pontoon
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A floating structure, usually rectangular in shape which serves as landing, pier head or bridge support. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3947)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Pylon/bridge support
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A vertical construction consisting, for example, of a steel framework or pre-stressed concrete to carry cables, a bridge, etc.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Radar station
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A station with a transmitter emitting pulses of ultra-high frequency radio waves which are reflected by solid objects and are detected upon their return to the sending station. (International Maritime Dictionary, 2nd Ed.)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The object 'radar station' is used to encode the technical equipment itself independent of the building or structure where it is installed. This building or structure, e.g. mast, tower, building, radar dome is a different object.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Railway
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A rail or set of parallel rails on which a train or tram runs. (Digital Geographic Information Working Group, Oct.87)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Recommended track
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A track recommended to all or only certain vessels. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 5576)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Recommended tracks include all channels recommended for hydrographic reasons to lead safely between shoal depths. The use of such tracks is generally left to the discretion of the mariner and will depend on the vessel's draught, the state of the tide, adequacy of navigational aids and so on. (IHO Chart Specifications, M-4) The recommended track is that portion of a 'navigation line' that a ship should use for navigation. (see below) In the case of a two-way recommended track, only one value of orientation is encoded (in the attribute ORIENT); the other value can be deduced (i.e. the value in ORIENT + 180 degrees) .

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Restricted area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A specified area designated by an appropriate authority within which navigation is restricted in accordance with certain specified conditions. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4366)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: River
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A relatively large natural stream of water. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4405)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The object 'river' describes the area of the river, the object 'river bank' its banks.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Road
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A road is an open way for the passage of vehicles. (United States Geological Survey, Jan.89)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Radar transponder beacon
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A transponder beacon, transmitting a coded signal on radar frequency, permitting an interrogating craft to determine the bearing and range of the transponder. Also called racon. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4137)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The object class 'radar transponder beacon' is only used to encode the technical equipment independent of the structure on which it is located (e.g. a beacon, light-vessel or tower).

AttributeBinding.format: xx.x-b,xx.x-b,...] xx.x = value in meter, b = band

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Sea area/named water area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A geographically defined part of the sea or other navigable waters. It may be specified within its limits by its proper name.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Each sea area is defined independent of any other. Smaller sea areas may be located within larger sea areas.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Silo/tank
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An enclosed container, used for storage (Digital Geographic Information Working Group, Oct.87)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Shoreline construction
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A fixed (not afloat) artificial structure between the water and the land, i.e. a man-made coastline.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Sloping ground
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An inclined surface (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4776).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Slope topline
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The upper marking of a slope, e.g. the ridge line or the separation line between two different gradients.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: no remark.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Small craft facility
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A place at which a service generally of interest to small craft or pleasure boats is available.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: This object class encodes the service available at this location. The structure housing the service should be encoded separately.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Sounding
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A measured water depth or spot which has been reduced to a vertical datum (may be a drying height).
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The value of the sounding is encoded in the 3-D Coordinate field of the Spatial Record Structure (see S-57 Part 3). Drying heights (drying soundings) are indicated by a negative value.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Topmark
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A characteristic shape secured at the top of a buoy, or beacon, to aid in its identification. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 5548)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The body carrying the topmark is a separate object.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Tunnel
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A passage that is open to the atmosphere at both ends, buried under the sea bed or laid over the sea floor or bored under the ground or through mountains.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Two-way route part
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A two-way route is a route within defined limits inside which two-way traffic is established, aimed at providing safe passage of ships through waters where navigation is difficult or dangerous. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 5712). A two-way route part is an area of a two-way route within which traffic flow is generally along one bearing (and possibly its reciprocal).
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The complete two-way route consists of one or more parts depending on the shape of the two-way route. The orientation of the two-way route part is defined by its centerline and is related to the general direction of the two-way route.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Underwater/awash rock
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A concreted mass of stony material or coral which dries, is awash or is below the water surface.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Vegetation
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Collections of, or individual plants.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Wreck
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The ruined remains of a stranded or sunken vessel which has been rendered useless. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 6027)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Aggregation
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Used to identify an aggregation of two or more objects. This aggregation may be named.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: An aggregation could be used to combine objects that are related in some way (is-a-part-of, is-a-component-of) into a higher level object. For example: an aggregation relationship may be used to form a traffic separation scheme from traffic separation lane parts, boundaries, etc.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Anchor berth
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A designated area of water where a single vessel, sea plane, etc... may anchor.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: In general the anchor berth is defined by the centre point and a swinging circle.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Anchorage area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area in which vessels anchor or may anchor. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 130)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Beacon, lateral
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A beacon, is a prominent specially constructed object forming a conspicuous mark as a fixed aid to navigation or for use in hydrographic survey (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 420). A lateral beacon, is used to indicate the port or starboard hand side of the route to be followed. They are generally used for well defined channels and are used in conjunction with a conventional direction of buoyage. (UKHO NP 735, 5th Edition)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Berth
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A named or numbered place where a vessel is moored at a wharf. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 470)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Bridge
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A structure erected over a depression or an obstacle such as a body of water, railroad, etc... to provide a roadway for vehicles, pedestrians or to carry utility services. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 544)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: A bridge may consist of portions which cover the land and the water. The bridge supports are encoded as pylon/bridge supports (PYLONS).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Bunker station
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A station, at which a ship is able to bunker fuel, water or ballast

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Buoy, lateral
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A buoy, is a floating object moored to the bottom in a particular place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 565). A lateral buoy, is used to indicate the right-hand or left-hand side of a channel limit in the waterway.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Cable, overhead
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An overhead cable is an assembly of wires or fibres, or a wire rope or chain, which is supported by structures such as poles or pylons and passing over or nearby navigable waters. (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy).
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The cable supports are encoded as pylon/bridge supports (PYLONS).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Checkpoint
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An official place to register, declare or check goods and people.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The object 'checkpoint' does not include facilities such as buildings, gates or other installations.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Communication area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Indicates the coverage of an area, in which a vessel has to report or may request information.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Conveyor
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A mechanical apparatus for moving bulk material or people from place to place (as by a moving belt or chain of receptacles).
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The conveyor supports are encoded as pylon/bridge supports (PYLONS).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Crane
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A machine for lifting, shifting and lowering objects or materials by means of a swinging boom or with a lifting apparatus supported on an overhead track. (Digital Geographic Information Working Group, Oct.87)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The position of a sheerlegs or a travelling crane is defined as its resting position.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Current, non-gravitational
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Currents (non-gravitational) include either singly or in combination: ocean currents (wind and/or density driven), inter-oceanic equalising currents, currents of navigable rivers, river outflow effects offshore and other non-tidal flows.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Depth area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A depth area is a water area whose depth is within a defined range of values.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Intertidal areas are encoded as depth areas. These do not have to include soundings. The depth range within a depth area is defined by the attributes 'DRVAL1' and 'DRVAL2'.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: distance mark
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A distance mark indicates the distance measured from an origin and consists of either a solid visible structure or a distinct location without special installation. Usually found on canals or rivers.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Exceptional navigation strcuture
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An exceptional navigational construction like aqueduct, lift-lock, etc.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Distinction: bridge, bridge area, lock basin, lock basin part, lock area.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Ferry route
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A route in a body of water where a ferry crosses from one shoreline to another. (Digital Geographic Information Working Group, Oct.87)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Floating dock
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A form of dry dock consisting of a floating structure of one or more sections which can be partly submerged by controlled flooding to receive a vessel, then raised by pumping out the water so that the vessel's bottom can be exposed. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1427)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Gate
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A structure that may be swung, drawn, or lowered to block an entrance or passageway. (United States Geological Survey, Jan.89)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: This object class is used to encode gates that control the flow of water.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Harbour area (administrative)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The term "harbour" applies only to the area of water with the works necessary for its forma-tion, protections and maintenance (International Maritime Dictionary, 2d. Edition). A harbour area not only covers the area of water but also the area of land which supplies the harbour installations.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Harbour basin
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An enclosed area of water surrounded by quay walls constructed to provide means for the transfer of cargos from and to ships (International Maritime Dictionary, 2d. Edtion).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Harbour facility
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A harbour installation with a service or commercial operation of public interest.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Hulk
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A permanently moored ship.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Lock basin
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A lock basin is a wet dock in a waterway, permitting a ship to pass from one level to another. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 2881)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The lock gates are encoded as separate gate objects (GATCON).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Lock basin part
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A lock basin is divided into several lock basin parts, if this lock basin has one ground level but several gates.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Maximum permitted ship dimensions
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Waterway or waterway section for which a juridical regulation with respect to the maximum permitted vessel dimensions exists.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Maximum permitted vessel speed
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Waterway or waterway section for which a juridical regulation with respect to the maximum permitted vessel speed exists.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Navigational system of marks
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area within which a specific system of navigational marks applies and/or a common direction of buoyage.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Notice mark
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A signboard used to indicate prohibitions, regulations, restrictions, recommendations and general information which apply to a waterway or a section of a waterway

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Pipeline, overhead
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A pipeline is a string of interconnected pipes used for the transport of matter, nowadays mainly oil or gas. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3857). An overhead pipeline is a pipeline supported by pylons and passing over or nearby navigable waters.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Pontoon
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A floating structure, usually rectangular in shape which serves as landing, pier head or bridge support. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3947)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: port area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Apart from harbours a port includes a city or borough with accommodation and facilities for landing passangers and goods and some amount of overseas trade. A port may possess a harbour but a harbour is not necessarily a port (International Maritime Dictionary, 2d. Edition).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Radio calling-in point
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Also called radio reporting points, they have been established in certain busy waterways and port approaches to assist traffic control. On passing these points or crossing a defined line vessels are required to report on VHF to a Traffic Control Centre. (adapted from IHO Chart Specifications, M-4)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The attribute 'orientation' (ORIENT) encodes the orientation of the traffic flow at that point.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: refuse dump
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: At a refuse dump ships are able to unload their refuse like waste oil or black water.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Restricted area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A specified area designated by an appropriate authority within which navigation is restricted in accordance with certain specified conditions. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4366)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Shoreline Construction
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A fixed (not afloat) artificial structure between the water and the land, i.e. a man-made coastline.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Signal station, traffic
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A signal station is a place on shore from which signals are made to ships at sea. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4742). Traffic signal stations regulate the movement of traffic. (IHO Chart Specifications, M-4)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: This object class is used to describe the function of the signal station rather than the structure on which the station is sited.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Signal station, warning
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A signal station is a place on shore from which signals are made to ships at sea. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4742)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: This object class is used to describe the function of the signal station rather than the structure on which the station is sited.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Sounding datum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area of uniform sounding datum.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: terminal
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A terminal covers that area on shore which provides buildings and constructions for the trans-fer of cargos from and to ships.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Time Schedule - in general
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A schedule listing events and the times at which they will take place (www.wordiq.com/dictionary).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: turning basin
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area of water or enlargement of a channel used for turning vessels (International Maritime Dictionary, 2d Edition).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Underwater rock / awash rock
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A concreted mass of stony material or coral which dries, is awash or is below the water surface.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Vehicle transfer
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A place where vehicles can be loaded or unloaded from the inland vessel with onboard or on-shore facilities.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Vertical datum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area of uniform vertical datum.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Waterway area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area in which uniform general information of the waterway exists.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: waterway axis
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The waterway axis can be defined by e.g: - the middle line of a fairway, (Definition of fairway: That part of a river, harbour; etc. where the main navigable channel for vessels of larger size lies. It is also the usual course followed by vessels entering or leaving harbours, called ship channel. (International Maritime Dictionary, 2nd Ed.). - the middle line of a water way (Definition of waterway: The waterway covers the entire area of a river or canal).
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The object name indicates the specific name of a public waterway/or part of waterway.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Waterway gauge
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A waterway gauge is an instrument for measuring water levels
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: This object is needed in order to develop a unique and standardized way of providing data and information about gauges on inland waterways. This way is a precondition of including informa-tion on actual water levels in order to refer depth data as well as vertical clearances at bridges etc. to the present situation on waterways.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: waterway profile
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A waterway profile is a physically non-existent line which is normally the connection of two op-posite distance marks. Waterway profiles can be used to define a special water level.
